verses.text: These are the heads of their families, and the genealogy of those who went up with me from Babylon, during the reign of King Artaxerxes:
verses.comment: Ezra begins by recording those who returned from exile, emphasizing the importance of fidelity to covenant and ancestry. The role of genealogies also foreshadows later New Testament genealogies pointing to Christ (see Matt 1:1-16).

verses.text: From the descendants of Phinehas: Gershom. From the descendants of Ithamar: Daniel. From the descendants of David: Hattush,
verses.comment: The mention of Phinehas and Ithamar ties the returnees to the priestly line, showing continuity of the sacrificial system, which mirrors Christ's ultimate priesthood (Heb. 7:26-28).

verses.text: from the descendants of Shecaniah, of the sons of Parosh: Zechariah, and with him were registered one hundred and fifty men.
verses.comment: Ezra carefully records the number of men, highlighting the importance of ordered, faithful communities, a principle echoed in the gathering of believers in Acts 2:41.

verses.text: From the descendants of Pahath-moab: Eliehoenai son of Zerahiah, and with him two hundred men;
verses.comment: Note the return of those exiled tribes, showing restoration and unity—prefiguring Christ's uniting work (Eph. 2:14-16).

verses.text: from the descendants of Zattu: Shecaniah son of Jahaziel, and with him three hundred men;
verses.comment: Shecaniah’s name appears multiple times, underscoring the healing of division and the security of true leadership (Acts 1:23-26).

verses.text: from the descendants of Adin: Ebed son of Jonathan, and with him fifty men;
verses.comment: ‘Ebed’ means ‘servant,’ a subtle call to humility and service, virtues championed by Christ (Mk 10:45).

verses.text: from the descendants of Elam: Jeshaiah son of Athaliah, and with him seventy men;
verses.comment: Seventy is biblically significant—see Luke 10:1 (sending out the seventy), which hints at God’s plan for a universal community of faith.

verses.text: from the descendants of Shephatiah: Zebadiah son of Michael, and with him eighty men;
verses.comment: The detail reflects careful stewardship, an echo to Christ’s parable of the talents (Matt 25:14-30).

verses.text: from the descendants of Joab: Obadiah son of Jehiel, and with him two hundred and eighteen men;
verses.comment: Obadiah is a name tied to prophetic heritage, which points to God’s continuous proclamation through His people.

verses.text: from the descendants of Bani: Shelomith son of Josiphiah, and with him one hundred and sixty men;
verses.comment: Such exact records reinforce the value of each individual in the community of faith (Rom. 12:5).

verses.text: from the descendants of Bebai: Zechariah son of Bebai, and with him twenty-eight men;
verses.comment: Though a small group, their inclusion reveals the principle of the faithful remnant preserved through history.

verses.text: from the descendants of Azgad: Johanan son of Hakkatan, and with him one hundred and ten men;
verses.comment: Johanan’s name later appears in leadership roles, paralleling ongoing succession in the Church.

verses.text: from the descendants of Adonikam: the last ones, whose names are Eliphelet, Jeuel, and Shemaiah, and with them sixty men;
verses.comment: The mention of ‘last ones’ may point symbolically to latter-day inclusion, echoing Gospel themes of the last being first (Luke 13:30).

verses.text: from the descendants of Bigvai: Uthai and Zabbud, and with them seventy men.
verses.comment: Seventy again recurs; see previous note on spiritual fullness and universality.

verses.text: I gathered them by the river that flows to Ahava, and we camped there for three days. I looked among the people and the priests, but did not find any descendants of Levi there.
verses.comment: The lack of Levites is notable: the priestly ministry is indispensable, reflected in the New Testament priesthood of Christ (Heb. 7:11-28).

verses.text: Then I sent for Eliezer, Ariel, Shemaiah, Elnathan, Jarib, Elnathan, Nathan, Zechariah, and Meshullam; leading men, also for Joiarib and Elnathan, both men of insight.
verses.comment: Selection of wise leaders echoes the apostolic practice found in Acts 6:3 and Acts 1:23-26.

verses.text: I sent them to Iddo, the leader at the place Casiphia, with instructions to tell him and his relatives, the temple servants at Casiphia, to send us ministers for the house of our God.
verses.comment: Temple service is interconnected with communal worship, resembling the liturgical nature seen throughout Scripture.

verses.text: By the gracious hand of our God upon us, they brought to us Sherebiah, a man of insight, from the descendants of Mahli, son of Levi, the son of Israel, together with his sons and brothers, eighteen in all;
verses.comment: Ezra recognizes God’s providential guidance, an affirmation of divine sovereignty mirrored throughout Christian history.

verses.text: and Hashabiah, with him Jeshaiah from the descendants of Merari, with his brothers and their sons, twenty in all;
verses.comment: The families of Levi and Merari are re-established, echoing the foundational nature of true worship.

verses.text: and besides them, the temple servants, whom David and the officials had set apart for service to the Levites, two hundred and twenty temple servants, all were listed by name.
verses.comment: Set apart temple servants hint at the necessity of sacred orders for liturgy, connecting Old Testament temple worship to the Church’s sacramental life.

verses.text: Then I proclaimed a fast there at the river Ahava, that we might humble ourselves before our God, to seek from Him a safe journey for us, our children, and all our possessions.
verses.comment: Fasting as a communal act of repentance and dependence upon God, anticipating later Christian practices of fasting and preparation (Matt. 6:16-18).

verses.text: For I was ashamed to ask the king for a band of soldiers and horsemen to protect us from enemies on the road, because we had told the king, ‘The hand of our God is for good on all who seek Him, but His power and wrath are against all who forsake Him.’
verses.comment: Ezra demonstrates spiritual trust over reliance on earthly power, encapsulating Christ’s Beatitudes (Matt. 5:5) and the teaching of humble reliance on God.

verses.text: So we fasted and sought our God for this, and He answered our prayer.
verses.comment: God responding to sincere prayer affirms faith in divine providence, a continual theme in both covenants.

verses.text: Then I set apart twelve of the leading priests: Sherebiah, Hashabiah, and ten of their relatives with them,
verses.comment: Twelve priests recall the twelve tribes and apostles, suggesting that leadership is fixed upon an established foundation.

verses.text: and I weighed out to them the silver, the gold, and the vessels, the contribution for the house of our God that the king, his counselors, his officials, and all Israel present there, had offered.
verses.comment: Material offerings for worship show the harmony of faith and works, a significant biblical theme (see James 2:17).

verses.text: I weighed into their hands six hundred and fifty talents of silver, silver vessels worth one hundred talents, one hundred talents of gold,
verses.comment: The meticulous record of offerings highlights the sacred trust invested in leaders—mirroring the stewardship required of the apostles and presbyters (Acts 20:28).

verses.text: twenty bowls of gold worth one thousand darics, and two fine vessels of polished bronze, as precious as gold.
verses.comment: The value placed on the vessels foreshadows the New Testament teaching that believers themselves are vessels of honor for God’s service (2 Tim. 2:20).

verses.text: And I said to them, ‘You are holy to the LORD, and the vessels are holy, and the silver and the gold are a freewill offering to the LORD, the God of your ancestors.’
verses.comment: The concept of holiness applies both to persons and elements used in worship, prefiguring what Paul teaches regarding the sanctification of believers (1 Pet. 2:5; Rom. 12:1).

verses.text: Guard them and keep them until you weigh them before the leading priests, the Levites, and the heads of the families of Israel at Jerusalem, within the chambers of the house of the LORD.
verses.comment: Accountability and transparency in the stewardship of holy things is a biblical principle that persists throughout Christian life and sacraments.

verses.text: So the priests and the Levites took the weight of the silver, the gold, and the vessels, to bring them to Jerusalem, to the house of our God.
verses.comment: The journey of sacred things into Jerusalem prefigures Christ’s own entering into Jerusalem to fulfill all worship and covenant (Luke 19:28-40).

verses.text: Then we departed from the river Ahava on the twelfth day of the first month, to go to Jerusalem. The hand of our God was upon us, and He delivered us from the hand of the enemy and ambushes along the way.
verses.comment: Ezra’s journey protected by God recalls Israel’s earlier exodus, and points to spiritual journeys guarded by divine providence (Ps. 121:7-8).

verses.text: We arrived at Jerusalem and rested there for three days.
verses.comment: Resting for three days can be spiritually interpreted as a foreshadowing of Christ’s resurrection after three days (Matt. 12:40).

verses.text: On the fourth day, within the house of our God, we weighed the silver and the gold and the vessels into the hands of Meremoth son of Uriah the priest, and with him was Eleazar son of Phinehas, and with them Jozabad son of Jeshua and Noadiah son of Binnui, the Levites.
verses.comment: The act of weighing the offerings in the temple demonstrates careful stewardship and sacredness of the Church’s treasures.

verses.text: Everything was counted and weighed, and all the weight was recorded at that time.
verses.comment: Divine order and fidelity are seen in careful record-keeping, reflecting Christ’s care for every soul (John 10:3).

verses.text: The exiles who had returned offered burnt offerings to the God of Israel: twelve bulls for all Israel, ninety-six rams, seventy-seven lambs, and as a sin offering twelve male goats. All of this was offered as a burnt offering to the LORD.
verses.comment: The detailed offerings signify atonement and thanksgiving; the number twelve symbolizes wholeness and unity of the people, anticipating later unity under Christ (see John 17:21).

verses.text: They delivered the king’s orders to the king’s satraps and to the governors beyond the River, and they aided the people and the house of God.
verses.comment: The cooperation of civil authorities with the worshiping community anticipates the proper relationship of Church and society (Rom. 13:1-7); it shows that spiritual works can be supported by temporal powers.
